27/12/2020

DAY 1 : Kangaroo island

View Image

DAY 1

Location: Adelaide

Activity: Kangaroo island

Kangaroo Island is just off the peninsula from Cape Jervis which is roughly an hour and 40 minutes from Adelaide CBD. The transport from Adelaide CBD to Cape Jervis is limited so you will need to either drive or book the Sealink coach service. The most recent timetable can be found at Public coach timetable Tickets cost $29 for the coach one way and $49 for the Ferry from Cape Jervis to Kangaroo Island. Kangaroo Island Ferry If you are driving you can take your car on to the Ferry for $98 each way. The Ferry crossing takes roughly 45 minutes.

There are 2 ways to explore the island, you will either need to hire a car(or take your own car over on the ferry) or book a tour as there isnt any public transport on the Island.

If you choose to hire a car, start your trip to Kangaroo Island by exploring the Islands wildlife. The Island is home to New Zealand Fur Seals at Cape de Couedic, Sea Lions in Seal Bay and Small Penguins at Pennshaw Penguin Centre. You should also keep an eye out for Koalas and Kangaroo along the way.

If its a warm day you can head to a secluded swimming spot like Vivonne Bay or pick a quiet beach like Stokes Bay or Emu Bay to spend the afternoon.

If youre looking for more active things to do on the Island you can book a Quad bike tour from $147 withKangaroo Island Quad Bike Tours or try some sand boarding and tobogganing from $37 at Little Sahara adventure centre

There are plenty of popular restaurants on the island, Pennshaw Beach and Kingscote both have a collection of Pizzerias, fish & chip shops and Australian restaurants.

If you are looking for a package tour that includes the best activities on the island as well as transport you should consider the 2 day tour 2 day Kangaroo Island wild explorer

DAY 2 : Rundle Mall

DAY 2

Location: Adelaide

Activity: Rundle Mall

DAY 3 : Adelaide-Zoo

DAY 3

DAY 4 : Barossa Valley

View Image

DAY 4

Location: Adelaide

Activity: Barossa Valley

The Barossa Valley is a must see whilst in Adelaide. It's one of the most famous Wine regions in the Australia, its recommended to spend the day hoping between wineries.

If you have a car you can drive out to the Barossa Valley which is roughly an hour away from ADelaide CBD and stay for the night in one of the boutique hotels. However you will need to book a taxi from your hotel to the wineries as you are likely to be drinking quite a bit at each location and won't be able to drive.

Alternatively you could book a day trip. There are lots to choose from that have very similar itineraries however one example is the Small Group Premium Wine Tour You will stop at 4 different wineries and enjoy some local foods along the way before being dropped back to the accommodation in Adelaide CBD or Glenelg.

Alternatively if you are looking for a slower paced day at the wineries you could opt for the Barossa Valley and Hahndorf Day Tour This tour visits 2 wineries in Barossa Valley as well as stopping at Hahndorf, a small historical town in the Adelaide Hills with little sweet shops and cafes and lots of German History.

Use this website to help narrow down which tour is best for you Amazing Barossa

DAY 5 : Hindley Street

View Image

DAY 5

Location: Adelaide

Activity: Hindley Street

DAY 6 : Glenelg

View Image

DAY 6

Location: Adelaide

Activity: Glenelg

Glenelg is the main beach town in Adelaide and is located a short 35minute FREE tram ride from the CBD. Glenelg is a long stretch of shallow shores and white sandy beaches and its a great spot to relax for the day.

When you arrive you should take a walk along the pier out to sea to get a view of the beach town before picking your spot on the sand for the day.

A popular attraction in Glenelg is the Beachhouse. The beachhouse is the perfect spot to find your inner child, you can go on the bumper cars, bumper boats, arcade games, mini golf or even the water slides just off the main beach.

If the Beachhouse entertainment centre isnt your thing maybe youd prefer a lunch date and cocktails on the beach at The Moseley Beach Club where you can lounge on day beds or picnic benches and sip your drink from a coconut.

Make sure you check out Glenelgs shops on Jetty Road, they have everything from boutique beach clothes to English sweet shops.

DAY 7 : Mount Lofty & Hahndorf

View Image

DAY 7

Location: Adelaide

Activity: Mount Lofty & Hahndorf

Mount Lofty is a lookout point across the whole of Adelaide just a 25 minute drive out of the City.

Mounty Lofty has 8 different walking tracks to the summit ranging from 2 to 4 hours (and back remember!) you can find out more about the walking tracks at Walking SA Alternatively you can drive straight to the summit. There is a car park with pay and display parking and a cafe at the lookout that serves hot food and snacks for breakfast, lunch and dinner.

Keep driving towards Hahndorf which is roughly 15-20 minutes away from the Mount Lofty summit. Hahndorf is a little German town hidden in the Adelaide Hills. Total journey time if driving from Adelaide is 50 minutes, via Mount Lofty or you can catch the 864F bus from Pulteney Street Adelaide (Subject to change so please use google maps) which will take roughly 1 hour.

Despite being a very small town Hahndorf has plenty to do, you can visit Hahndorf Farm Barn and feed the animals, pick Strawberries at Beerenberg Family Farm, visit the German Migration Museum, play a round of mini golf or even just browse the Main Street and try out some of the ale houses.

There are lots of places to eat including Udder Delights Cheese Cellar for an amazing cheese board or Haus for German dishes or pizzas.

If you dont have a car to explore and you dont fancy catching public transport you could opt for a day trip such as 1 Day Adelaide City and Hahndorf Tour. The tour is only 4 hours so you may not get a chance to do everything whilst in Hahndorf or hike at Mount Lofty but if you are strapped for time this is a good alternative to tick it off the bucketlist.

Travel Directions : Adelaide-Melbourne

Location: Adelaide-Melbourne

Activity: Travel

If you have a car you can drive from Adelaide to Melbourne via the famous Great Ocean Road. The total journey is roughly 11 and a half hours. If you have time to spare or if you already planned to visit the Great Ocean Road its worth stopping in Warnambool overnight to break up the journey and enjoy a slower drive along the Great Ocean Road the following day. If youre looking for a shorter journey you can take the inland route which is roughly an 8 hour drive. If youre on a tight time frame you should fly from Adelaide to Melbourne, its a 1 hour and 15 minute flight and can be as cheap as $60 one way. You can also catch a train from Adelaide to Melbourne changing at Nhill from $114. The journey time is roughly 11hours from start to finish.

Travel Directions : Melbourne-Adelaide

Location: Melbourne-Adelaide

Activity: Travel

If you have a car you can drive from Melbourne to Adelaide via the famous Great Ocean Road. The total journey is roughly 11 and a half hours. If you have time to spare or if you already planned to visit the Great Ocean Road its worth enjoying the drive at a slower pace and then stopping in Warnambool overnight to break up the journey before continuing the journey the following day. If youre looking for a shorter journey you can take the inland route which is roughly an 8 hour drive.

Alternatively you can catch a train from Melbourne to Adelaide changing at Nhill from just $114. The journey time is roughly 11hours from start to finish.

If youre on a tight time frame you should fly from Melbourne to Adelaide, its a 1 hour and 15 minute flight and can be as cheap as $60 one way however this could become a lot more expensive depending on when you are travelling.

DAY 8 : Great Ocean Road -The 12 Apostles

View Image

DAY 8

Location: Melbourne

Activity: Great Ocean Road -The 12 Apostles

Hire a car for 2 days to drive the Great Ocean Road. The most savy way to drive the Great ocean Road is actually a little backwards.

Drive inland direct to the 12 apostles. The earlier you can get here the better because there will be lots of coach tours passing through from mid- morning onwards. Most tours only go as far as the 12 Apostles meaning the second half of the route is a lot quieter. Continue North West towards Adelaide as far as Port Fairy which is technically classed the end of the Great Ocean Road, its a small town with a few restaurants to stop for dinner. You can stay overnight in Warnanbool which is an area roughly 30 mins before the end of the Great Ocean Road with shops and restaurants and lots of hotels.

The Great Ocean Road has lots of beauty spots along the route so here are the most recommended for this section of the Great Ocean Road.

The 12 apostles- This is the most famous stop on the Great Ocean Road, although there are technically only 8 apostles left. There will be lots of tour coaches arriving here so make sure you get here early.

Gibson steps- A short walk from the 12 apostles, you can walk down to beach on the opposite side of the peninsula at the 12 apostles. The walk will take roughly 30mins each way to get down to the beach.

Loch Ard Gorg.- Another nice view point just 3 minutes West of the 12 Apostles. You can get down to the beach here too if you fancy relaxing on a sunny day.

London Bridge- The next stop just beyond the 12 apostles. Its a quick stop with lookout platforms over what has been named the London Bridge due to a large section falling down in to the sea.

The Grotto- Roughly 5 minutes beyond London Bridge. The Grotto is a popular spot for taking pictures. Its roughly a 750m walk from the car park down to the Grotto where you will be able to see through the cave and out to the Ocean. A popular instagrammable stop.

(There are many other stops along this route so you may have more time to explore the rest depending on how long you stop for)

DAY 9 : Great Ocean Road -The Full Drive

View Image

DAY 9

Location: Melbourne

Activity: Great Ocean Road -The Full Drive

Day 2, leave early and get on the road heading back passed the 12 apostles, having covered this already youll be able to enjoy the drive straight passed the 12 apostles and on to the next hot spots. You will then be on the road early enough to do the full drive and you will also be driving in the opposite direction to the traffic giving you a little more privacy at each stop and less traffic on the route home.

Wreck Beach(wattlehill)- A good spot to stretch your legs. A secluded beach about a 15min drive on an off road track.(Must have a 4WD) You can either hike up to a look out which can take upto 40mins or take the 375 steps down to the beach. If the tide is low there are 2 anchors visible from shipwrecks that have slowly been washed away over the years.

Cape Otway- A large National Park with lots of hikes to choose from. You can also visit the Lightstation Lightstation for $18.50 and listen to the guide talks as well as walk up to the top of the light house.

Apollo Bay- A coastal Town which is a great place to stop, there are lots of different restaurants, here are trip advisors top 10 Apollo Bay restaurants Whilst in Apollo Bay you can head to the beach for some sun or even book a kayaking tour (90 minutes) to head out looking for fur seals. Apollo Bay Surf & Kayak the tours are $85, or alternatively you could hire some Stand Up paddle boards or take a surf lesson to break up the journey before getting back on the road towards Melbourne.

Grey River road, Kennet River- Its a short detour off the Great Ocean Road but its worth it to spot some Koalas, as you pull on to the Grey River Road (a short 10 minute detour off of the Great Ocean Road) keep your eyes peeled for the Koalas that live here.

Eastern View- The start of the great ocean road and where you will find The memorial Arch sign. A very quick photo stop to get a picture with the Great Ocean Road sign. From here it is roughly 2 hours back to Melbourne CBD.

There are a few other popular beach towns on the drive back to Melbourne such as Lorne, Torquay and Bells Beach which are also other possible stops for lunch and dinner depending on the time you have.

DAY 10 : Melbourne Zoo

View Image

DAY 10

Location: Melbourne

Activity: Melbourne Zoo

The Melbourne Zoo is open every day from 09:00 17:00. Trains run to Royal Park Station on the Upfield Line. Take Tram 55 which runs from William St in the city and stops in front of the zoo. Tickets are $38 and can be purchased online or on the day. You can also book up close experiences with Gorillas, Giraffes and even the Tigers.

The Zoo has 3 cafes onsite so you can enjoy, The Lakeside Cafe, the Elephant Cafe and the Giraffe Lookout Cafe.

DAY 11 : The Art Scene

View Image

DAY 11

Location: Melbourne

Activity: The Art Scene

Melbourne is known as one of the worlds great street art capitals for its unique expressions of art displayed on approved outdoor locations throughout the city. Here are a few streets featuring great works; Hosier and Rutledge Lane, opposite Federation Square, Caledonian Lane, off Little Bourke Street, Union Lane, off Bourke Street Mall, Rear of 280 Queen Street in Finlay Avenue, 21 Degraves Street, Corner of Flinders Lane and Cocker Alley , 122 Palmerston Street, Carlton.

The area out near the Rose Street Artists Market is another great area. It isnt just street art that Melbourne has to offer. Visit the National Gallery of Victoria (NGV) located over the bridge from Federation Square pass the Arts Centre. Houses an extensive collection from Europe, Asia, America, and Oceania. General entry is free and the gallery is open 10:00 17:00 every day.

The Ian Potter Centre located in Federation Square houses Australian art, presenting Indigenous and non-Indigenous art from the colonial period to the present day. General entry is free and the gallery is open 10:00 17:00.

DAY 12 : St Kilda

View Image

DAY 12

Location: Melbourne

Activity: St Kilda

Take the tram to St Kilda to visit Melbournes closest beach (Very different to the beaches on the East Coast). The quickest way to get there is the Tram, take the 96 from Bourke Street towards St Kilda. St. Kilda is a beachside destination about a 20 minute tram ride away. If it's a warm day head to Stand Up Paddle Board HQ to hire a SUP. You can hire a board for $30 for an hour between 9am and 1pm. Stand Up Paddle Board HQ

Whilst your here check out Luna Park!

Luna Park is an old carnival style theme park at St. Kilda. It is generally open on the weekends and is free to enter. A ride costs $10.95 or you can buy unlimited rides for $47.50.

Acland Street is a street in the Melbourne suburb of St Kilda, which enjoys great popularity as a recreational area, mainly due to its many restaurants and its proximity to the entertainment areas along St Kilda beach. Have a wine at The Vineyard or have a coffee and cheesecake at Monarch Cakes. Down by the beach is a cool bar Republica that has a great menu.

Take the Tram 16 back to the city (as opposed to the 96). This way you will travel along St. Kilda Rd and have an opportunity to jump off at the Shrine of Remembrance, Victorias memorial to the men and women who have served Australia in armed conflicts and peace keeping missions. The Shrine is open 10:00 17:00 every day. You could also wander through a section of the Botanic Gardens as you take the 1.3 km walk back to Federation Square.

DAY 13 : Shop till you drop!

View Image

DAY 13

Location: Melbourne

Activity: Shop till you drop!

Melbourne's retail heart on Bourke St Mall links Swanston and Elizabeth streets and is only open to trams and pedestrians. Listen out for the bells of approaching trams as you drift between department stores and the flagship stores. Along Bourke St youll also find Australias two main department stores, Myer & David Jones. Melbournes GPO from 1854 is a multi-level shopping complex featuring H&M and similar stores. A short walk away is Emporium, with upmarket retailers and a great food court.

For both a cultural and shopping experience head to The Queen Victoria Market. Spread over several city blocks with over 600 retailers the market is a reflection of Melbournes cosmopolitan make-up. Fruit, vegetables, local and imported goods, fashion and souvenirs. Warm up in the winter months with a hot jam donut and a coffee. Listen to the butchers advertise their specials and sample some artisan cheese and breads. The market is closed on Mondays. The left hand column is the fresh produce section and the right hand column is the specialty shopping section.

The Market is only a 7 minute walk from Melbourne Central Station (along Elizabeth Street) and Flagstaff Station (along William Street). The market is also accessible with the free City Circle Tram.

For an awesome off-the-beaten-track market head out to the Rose Street Artists Market where emerging artists and designers showcase their work over the weekend. Check out quirky furniture, fashion, intricate jewellery, paintings and postcards. 60 Rose St Fitzroy, in between Brunswick and Nicholson Streets. Sat Sun 11:00 17:00.

From the city catch tram 96 from Bourke St (get off at stop 16) or 11 from Collins St. (get off at stop 17). The trip takes about 15 minutes. Prahan Market is known as the Food Lovers Market. Take Tram no.72 to Camberwell rom Swanston Street. Jump off at stop no. 30 outside of the market. The market is open Tues, Thurs, Fri, Sat 07:00 17:00. The market is open 10:00 15:00.

DAY 14 : Melbourne SEALife Aquarium

View Image

DAY 14

Location: Melbourne

Activity: Melbourne SEALife Aquarium

The Melbourne Aquarium is accessible with the free city tram or a 5 minute walk from Flinders Street or Southern Cross Stations. Tickets cost $46 or you can save up to 15% by purchasing online. Melbourne Aquarium is open from 09:30am -18:00pm with last entry at 17:00pm. Melbourne Aquarium is home to 10,000 aquatic animals including a 750kg salt water croc named Pinjarra. If youre looking for a more interactive experience you can book a Glass bottom boat experience with Stingray feeding.

A short walk from Melbourne Aquarium is Tattersalls Lane in Chinatown where you will find Section 8, an open-air bar built with shipping containers, great for day drinking!

DAY 15 : Special Interest Museums

View Image

DAY 15

Location: Melbourne

Activity: Special Interest Museums

A multicultural city with influences from all over world adding to the melting pot that is Melbourne.

The Immigration Museum is a museum primarily displaying Australia's immigration history. It is located on Flinders Street in Melbourne, Victoria, in the Old Customs House. Accessible on Free Tram or a short walk from Flinders Street or Southern Cross Stations. Entry is just $14.00 and the museum is open from 10:00am 17:00pm.

Melbourne Museum showcases Australian social history, indigenous cultures, science and the environment. It is a nice walk from the City where you can check out the Carlton Gardens and Exhibition Building. It is also home to IMAX Theatre. Opening times are 10:00am 17:00pm and entry is $15.00. IMAX tickets start from $15.00.

One of Australias most iconic figures was the bushranger Ned Kelly. Villain or hero, his story has lived on since his death at the Old Melbourne Gaol in 1880. The gaol runs various night tours including a ghost tour.

To see the original armour Ned Kelly wore in his last stand against the police you can visit the State Library of Victoria, opposite Melbourne Central Station. Visit between 10:00am and 17:00pm.

DAY 16 : Tour the City

View Image

DAY 16

Location: Melbourne

Activity: Tour the City

Whilst in Melbourne you will end up in Federation Square at some stage, its a great central meeting point to discover the culture of Melbourne.

The square has some great pubs and restaurants such as the River Bar or Transport to start or finish your walk around the City.

Walk from Federation Square along Birrarung Mar to the Sporting District.

Melbournes Australian Open tennis courts and Cricket Ground are often hosting sporting events with great atmosphere. You can take a tour of the MCG FOR $31.50pp, tours normally last around 75 minutes.

If sports isnt your thing you could cross the bridge from Federation square and head to South bank where youll find endless bars and restaurants as well as Crown Casino. Southbank has a market on Sunday between 10:00 and 16:00. Southbank generally has great buskers and street artists.

If its a clear day head up to the Eureka Skydeck for a view from above that stands 88 floors tall. Its $20 entry to take in the 360 view of Melbourne. Theres also an option to walk out onto a boxed in platform with a glass bottom for an additional $12.

DAY 17 : Brighton Bathing Boxes

View Image

DAY 17

Location: Melbourne

Activity: Brighton Bathing Boxes

The Brighton Bathing boxes often feature in Melbournes Tourism campaigns so its worth heading out for the City for a day to see them for yourselves. A train from the city will take around 20 minutes on the Sandringham line. Catch it from Flinders Street Station to Brighton Beach Railway Station and take the scenic 500-metre stroll down to the multi-coloured bathing boxes.

The Baths, Middle Brighton has a deck overlooking the beach and has a great breakfast/lunch menu aswell as cocktails and milkshakes. There is also kiosk if you just wanted to grab a coffee and a snack as you walk along the promenade.

Spend the afternoon swimming and sunbathing or walk along the beachfront stopping at the dog parks and peaking in at the mega mansions along the beachfront.

DAY 18 : Grafitti Laneways

View Image

DAY 18

Location: Melbourne

Activity: Grafitti Laneways

Arrive in Melbourne and spend the day in the City. Have a walk along the Graffiti Laneways, for example Hosier Lane, Degraves Street, Union Lane and Caledonian Lane are full of street art.

It's also worth checking out the historic arcades to get a feel for the Melbourne culture. Check out Royal arcade and Block arcade on your way to Bourke street mall for some shopping.

In the evening head to Curtin House Rooftop Bar to experience Melbourne nightlife. Melbourne is known for its cool bars and coffee shops

DAY 19 : Philip Island Day Trip

View Image

DAY 19

Location: Melbourne

Activity: Philip Island Day Trip

Philip Island Day trip is the best place to see Melbournes Fairy Penguins. A day tour will give you access to the wildlife park and also let you see the thousands of penguins come out of the ocean at dusk to sleep under the rocks on the beach. Philip Island Tour

Philip Island is just a 90 minute drive south of Melbourne City. The Island is full of wildlife and youll be able to get up close with Koalas, wombats and Dingos as well as catch the world famous Penguin parade. The Penguin Parade happens at dusk when around 4000 tiny penguin come out of the sea and walk to their little homes within the rocks for the night. You can either make your own way to Philip Island and book on to a penguin parade tour or you can take a day trip that will pick you up from Melbourne. The day trips are all day so its worth taking a few snacks for the journey etc however there will be opportunities to grab some food along the way.

1 Day Philip Island Tour

If youre also interested in doing the Great Ocean Road its worth looking at 2 Day Philip Island and Great Ocean Road Tour as it combines both on a 2 day tour.

DAY 20 : Yarra Valley Day Trip

View Image

DAY 20

Location: Melbourne

Activity: Yarra Valley Day Trip

Another popular day trip is out to the Yarra Valley Wineries. You could do this as a paid day trip, which we would recommend, so that you can enjoy the tastings at the wineries. Otherwise if you have your own vehicle and you are happy to be the designated driver its just over an hour out of town. There are plenty of options. Chandon has a popular tasting menu and cheese plates.

Yarra Valley Wine Tours go to different wineries, the chocolate factory and also provide lunch. Yarra Valley Gourmet Tour

DAY 21 : Mornington Peninsula

View Image

DAY 21

Location: Melbourne

Activity: Mornington Peninsula

Drive to Mornington Peninsula and spend a day at the Hot Springs and spa. You can get a day pass to enjoy the springs or if you want to treat yourself you could book a spa package. Mornington Peninsula Spa

You can stay the night at the spa or look for alternative accommodation nearby which is likely to be a bit cheaper. If you are missing the East Coast beaches you can drive to Mount Martha beach which is on the Mornington Peninsula. A really private beach lined with colourful beach huts located just passed the main town of Frankston.

Sorrento is another beach town worth visiting, it's right on the tip of the peninsula and has some of the best beach spots in Melbourne.

DAY 22 : Wilsons Prom- Hike Mt Oberon

View Image

DAY 22

Location: Melbourne

Activity: Wilsons Prom- Hike Mt Oberon

Wilsons Promontory, known as Wilsons Prom is just under a 3 hour drive from Melbourne via the M1. It's considered a little holiday destination away from the City. Drive down for an overnight stay in the National Park. There is a National Park entry fee of $9.

Head towards Telegraph Saddle carpark where you will find the start of the 3.4km hike to the top of Mt Oberon for sunset. The hike should take roughly 45minutes to 1 hour. The view from the top is epic especially at sunset.

There are some nice accommodation spots here however they can be pricey for those on a budget, most spots starting from $95 a night so make sure you do your research in advance and check what is available. If youre looking for a unique stay then why not try out the Tidal River Luxury Glamping accommodation.

Alternatively if you have a camper van there are lots of camping options in the area.

DAY 23 : Wilsons Prom- Beach Day

View Image

DAY 23

Location: Melbourne

Activity: Wilsons Prom- Beach Day

Wilsons Prom has some of the best beaches in Victoria so spend the day beach hopping from Wilsons Promontory Beach to refugee Cove and Squeaky beach (yes its so clean it sqeaks when you walk on it). Take a slow day exploring the National Park and then grab some Fish and Chips to enjoy on the beach for lunch before you make the drive back to Melbourne.

Travel Directions : Melbourne-Canberra

Location: Melbourne-Canberra

Activity: Travel

If you have a car you can drive from Melbourne to Canberra via the M31. The total journey is roughly 7 hours.

If youre using public transport you can catch a train from Southern Cross Station to Jolimont Tourist Centre in Canberra changing at Wodonga. Total journey time is just under 9 hours and train prices cost between $70-$200 depending on when you are travelling.

You can also choose to travel by Greyhound bus which run twice a day and take 8 hours. Average price is $90-150 again depending on what day/season you are travelling.

Finally you can chose to fly between Melbourne to Canberra. The flight is just 1 hour and starting price is $150 however may vary depending on date/ season you are travelling.

Travel Directions : Canberra-Melbourne

Location: Canberra-Melbourne

Activity: Travel

If you have a car you can drive from Canberra to Melbourne via the M31. The total journey is roughly 7 hours.

If youre using public transport you can catch a train from Jolimont Tourist Centre in Canberra to Southern Cross Station in Melbourne, changing at Wodonga. Total journey time is just under 9 hours and train prices cost between $70-$200 depending on when you are travelling.

You can also choose to travel by Greyhound bus which run twice a day(morning and overnight) and take 8 hours. Average price is $90-150 again depending on what day/season you are travelling.

Finally you can chose to fly between Melbourne to Canberra. The flight is just 1 hour and starting price is $150 however may vary depending on date/ season you are travelling.

Travel Directions : Melbourne-Sydney

Location: Melbourne-Sydney

Activity: Travel

Flying between Melbourne and Sydney is the most practical way to travel. The flight time is roughly 1hour and 25 minutes and prices can be as low as $70. However in peak seasons prices could reach over $250.

As an alternative you could catch a train from Melbournes Southern Cross station, to Sydneys Central Station. The journey time is 13hours and prices can range from $65 to $250 also.

Greyhound Buses run 3 times a day and have a journey time between 11 and a half and 12 and a half hours. Prices are on average between $60- $200.

If you are driving between these states take the M31 inland which should take you just under 9 hours(traffic depending)

Travel Directions : Sydney-Melbourne

Location: Sydney-Melbourne

Activity: Travel

Flying between Sydney and Melbourne is the most practical way to travel. The flight time is roughly 1hour and 25 minutes and prices can be as low as $70. However in peak seasons prices could reach over $250.

As an alternative you could catch a train from Sydneys Central Station to Melbournes Southern Cross station. The journey time is 13hours and prices can range from $65 to $250 also.
